text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
Updated the reference to Special Review’s IRM from IRM 4.71.15 to IRM 4.70.7.
This supersedes IRM 4.71.19 dated June 12, 2018.

) Purpose: IRM

, Employee Plans Examination of Returns, Fast Track Settlement Procedures, provides an alternative method for exam agents to resolve certain unagreed issues that are ineligible for resolution under or a DO
agreement. Before the Fast Track Settlement (FTS) program, these issues could only be handled under the traditional unagreed Day) route. (
) Audience: This IRM provides procedures for agents, their group managers and support staff in EP Examinations. (
) Policy Owner: Director, EP Examinations. (
) Program Owner: EP Examinations. (
) Program Authority: EP Examinations’ authority to conduct examinations, resolve issues and determine tax liability is derived from Title
, Internal Revenue Code, Subtitle F – Procedure and Administration, which includes is not limited to:. a. IRC section
- Examination of books and witnesses, which falls under Chapter
- Discovery of Liability and Enforcement of Title. Note: IRC
provides agents with the authority to: (cid:
) Audit any books, papers, records or other data necessary to complete an audit. (cid:
) Take testimony under oath to secure additional information needed.(cid:
)Issuesummons for information necessary to complete an audit. (cid:
) Ask about any offense connected to the administering or of the Internal Revenue laws. b. IRC section
- Assessment authority, which falls under Chapter
- Assessment. Note: EP Examinations’ authority to resolve issues is derived from its authority to make determinations of tax liability under IRC
) Program Goals: The information in this IRM allows EP Examinations to use FTS for certain unagreed issues resulting from a TE/GE examination or a Form
discrepancy adjustment. (
) EP Mandatory Review is the author of this IRM section. For questions, infor- mation or suggestions, contact the manager of EP Mandatory Review (
) EP Examinations is the division designated to resolve certain unagreed using the FTS terms outlined in this IRM. (
) Announcement
, IRB
is the authority for resolving unagreed issues raised during a TE/GE examination or Form
dis- crepancy adjustment that cannot be resolved through EPCRS or a DO
agreement. (

Note: EP Examinations’ authority to resolve issues is derived from its authority to make determinations of tax liability under IRC 6201.
EP Examinations established two review groups to make sure agents conduct examinations per technical, procedural and administrative requirements:
Employee Plans Examination of Returns
a. Mandatory Review, see IRM
, Employee Plans Examination of Returns, EP Mandatory Review. b. Special Review, see IRM
, Special Review (SR) and Tax Exempt Quality Measurement System (TEQMS) Procedures. (
) Tax Exempt Quality Measurement System (TEQMS) is the quality control system TE/GE uses to oversee the entire examination program. For more in- formation on TEQMS, see IRM
, Special Review (SR) and Tax Exempt Quality Measurement System (TEQMS) Procedures. (
) All examinations will be done in accordance with the Taxpayer Bill of Rights listed in IRC
Note: Find additional information at: Taxpayer Bill of Rights
) The IRS is fully committed to protecting the privacy rights of taxpayers and employees. Privacy laws are included in the IRC, the Privacy Act of

, the Freedom of Information Act, and IRS policies and practices. For more tion about these laws, visit the IRS Electronic Freedom of Information Act Reading Room. For questions concerning privacy, send an email to *Privacy. For question concerning disclosure, send an email to *Disclosure.
This manual uses the following acronyms and references the following forms.

Form Name Form 990-T Exempt Organization Business Income Tax Return Form 1040 U.S. Individual Income Tax Return Form 1120 U.S. Corporation Income Tax Return Form 5330 Return of Excise Taxes Related to Employee Beneﬁt Plans Form 2848 Power of Attorney and Declaration of Representa- tive Form 14017 Application for Fast Track Settlement Form 5599 TE/GE Examined Closing Record Form 1900 Income Tax Survey After Assignment Form 5772-A Employee Plans (EP) Workpaper Summary Form 5773-A Employee Plans (EP) Workpaper Continuation Sheet Form 10329 Transmittal Sheet-Related Cases
A pilot Appeals FTS program enabled taxpayers under TE/GE EP to certain unagreed issues while the case was still open in an EP ﬁeld nouncement
, IRB
, FTS for TE/GE Taxpayers. FTS was permanently established as a nationwide program to resolve certain unagreed issues raised through a TE/GE examination or
discrepancy adjustment (Announcement
). FTS is not available to resolve issues that can be resolved through EPCRS or a Delegation Order
(DO
) closing agreement. EP can only use FTS to resolve unagreed issues in these cases: a. Form
exams b. Form
-T exams c. Form
discrepancy adjustments d. Form
discrepancy adjustments e. Penalties related to an EP Examinations case. Note: EP can’t use FTS to resolve penalties under IRC

FTS enables EP entities (taxpayers) that have unagreed issues in at open period under examination to work with EP (agent and group and the Office of Appeals (Appeals) to resolve outstanding disputed while the case is still in EP jurisdiction. All three parties:
(10-28-2019) Overview of Fast Track Settlement (FTS) Program
is not available to resolve issues that can be resolved through either or a Delegation Order 8-3 (DO 8-3) closing agreement.

FTS enables EP entities (taxpayers) that have unagreed issues in at least one open period under examination to work with EP (agent and group manager) and the Office of Appeals (Appeals) to resolve outstanding disputed issues while the case is still in EP jurisdiction. All three parties:
Employee Plans Examination of a. Are active participants in the process. b. Must agree before a proposed resolution can be put in place. (
) TE/GE and Appeals jointly administer the FTS process. (
) FTS is used to resolve factual and legal issues. (
) FTS may be initiated at any time after an issue has been fully developed, before the
-Day letter is issued. (

) Under FTS, the EP group manager or designee: a. Coordinates preparation and submission of the application package. b. Notiﬁes the taxpayer of acceptance/rejection into/from the FTS c. Participates in the FTS Session on behalf of the government. d. Is primarily responsible for accepting or rejecting any settlement offered. (
) The FTS application is reviewed by both the group manager and the Area Manager (or designee) before it is sent to the Appeals FTS Program for ﬁnal approval. (
) The Appeals Team Manager responsible for TE/GE programs serves as the Appeals FTS Program Manager. (
) In managing cases eligible for FTS, the Appeals FTS Program Manager may consult with the EP group manager. (
) FTS is designed to be completed in approximately
days from the date a case is accepted into the FTS program. (
) The prohibition against ex parte communications between AOs and other employees provided under Section
(a) of the Restructuring and Reform Act of

does not apply to communications in the FTS process because Appeal employees are facilitating an agreement between the taxpayer and examination and are not acting in their traditional Appeals settlement role. (
) If the parties fail to resolve any issue in FTS, the taxpayer may still request that the issue be heard through the traditional Appeals process. (
) FTS is generally available for the following non-docketed EP cases: a. Form
exams and b. Form
-T exams c. Form
discrepancy adjustments d. Penalties related to Forms
-T or
discrepancy ments (
) FTS is generally not available for the following EP cases: a. Qualiﬁcation issues under IRC
(a) Note: Resolve these cases through EPCRS or through a DO
agreement. See IRM

, Closing Agreements. b. Where the taxpayer has failed to respond to IRS communications and documentation has been previously submitted for consideration. c. Listed Transactions or Abusive Tax Avoidance Transactions (ATATs). Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
D
Employee Plans Examination of Returns
If the parties fail to resolve any issue in FTS, the taxpayer may still request that the issue be heard through the traditional Appeals process.

Track Settlement Procedures 4.71.19
d. Where Appeals has no jurisdiction (for example IRC

penalty e. Speciﬁcally excluded from FTS, by the IRS Commissioner, Chief or by a Director in EP. f. Correspondence exams worked solely from a Campus site. g. TEFRA partnership cases. h. Issues under consideration or designated for litigation. i. Involving potential for civil or criminal fraud. j. “Whipsaw” issues (in other words issues for which resolution with to one party might result in inconsistent treatment in the absence of participation of another party). (
) The taxpayer, the examining agent, or the group manager may initiate an plication to the FTS process at any time after an issue has been fully developed, but before a
-Day letter is issued. (

) A taxpayer interested in participating in FTS, or one with questions about program and its suitability for their case, should contact the examining manager to discuss resolving an issue for the period(s) currently under nation. (
) To participate in FTS, the taxpayer must consent, per IRC
(c), to the taxpayer’s returns and return information for the issues being the FTS process to the individuals named on Form
, Application for Track Settlement. (
) To apply for the FTS program, the taxpayer should submit a completed signed Form
) Before submitting Form
to Appeals: a. The examining agent must write up all unagreed issues under the process, in a Revenue Agent Report (RAR) prepared per paragraph of IRM
(Form
), IRM

-T). b. The taxpayer must prepare a full written response explaining their position on each issue. Note: Form

Note: Form 14017, the RAR and the taxpayer’s written position are referred to as the FTS Submission Package.

referred to as the FTS Submission Package. EP group and area managers (or designee) will review the FTS Package before sending it to Appeals. After the FTS Submission Package is approved by the group manager Area Manager, the EP agent will email it to the Appeals FTS Program using the following email address: *AP TEGE FTS. Submission of the approved and signed Form

to the Appeals FTS Program Manager must be done within ﬁve business days of receipt. Within three business days of receipt of the FTS package, the Appeals Program Manager (or designee) will review the FTS Submission Package. If the case is accepted for inclusion in FTS, the Appeals FTS Program Manager (or designee) will:
Within three business days of receipt of the FTS package, the Appeals FTS Program Manager (or designee) will review the FTS Submission Package.
Employee Plans Examination of Returns

a. Contact the taxpayer to inform them that the case has been accepted FTS. b. Contact the EP group manager to inform him/her that the case has accepted for FTS. c. Assign an FTS Appeals officer who will act as the FTS Appeals Official (FTS AO) to help resolve the case. (

) If the case is rejected for inclusion in FTS, the Appeals FTS Program (or designee) will: a. Contact the EP group manager to inform him/her that the case has rejected for FTS. b. Call the taxpayer and send them a letter informing them that the case has been rejected for FTS. c. Discuss other dispute resolution opportunities with the taxpayer,
-Day letter procedures and the taxpayer’s normal Appeal rights.

Contact the taxpayer to inform them that the case has been accepted for FTS. Contact the EP group manager to inform him/her that the case has been accepted for FTS. Assign an FTS Appeals officer who will act as the FTS Appeals Official (FTS AO) to help resolve the case.

a. Contact the EP group manager to inform him/her that the case has been rejected for FTS. b. Call the taxpayer and send them a letter informing them that the case has been rejected for FTS. c. Discuss other dispute resolution opportunities with the taxpayer, including
-Day letter procedures and the taxpayer’s normal Appeal rights.
Note: The decision not to accept a case into the FTS program is not subject to ministrative appeal or judicial review. (
) During the FTS process the agent is responsible for protecting the statute of limitations. (

) If the case is accepted for FTS, the FTS AO: a. Will contact the EP group manager (or EP agent) and the taxpayer to up a meeting to discuss case resolution (the FTS Session). The FTS will stress to the taxpayer that the decision makers must be present. b. Will schedule the FTS Session at a mutually agreed upon date and location. Note: Due to IRS budget considerations, a face-to-face meeting at the taxpayer’s closest IRS office may not be possible. In such cases, the FTS Session may be held via a conference call or by other means. c. Will meet with the taxpayer (and/or their representative), the EP group manager (or designee) and the agent at the FTS Session. d. Will serve as a neutral party at the FTS Session. e. Does not perform in a traditional Appeals role, but uses dispute techniques to help resolve disputes between the parties. (
) Both parties can withdraw at any time during the FTS process. A party to withdraw must provide written notice to the FTS AO and other party. (
) At least one person with decision-making authority from both the taxpayer EP must be present during the FTS session. (
) The FTS Session may also include other individuals with decision making authority, information and expertise to assist the parties during the process. (
) The FTS AO may ask the taxpayer and the agent to limit the number of pants at the FTS Session to facilitate the process.
Note: The decision not to accept a case into the FTS program is not subject to ad- ministrative appeal or judicial review.
) Both parties can withdraw at any time during the FTS process. A party to withdraw must provide written notice to the FTS AO and other party. (
) At least one person with decision-making authority from both the taxpayer EP must be present during the FTS session. (
) The FTS Session may also include other individuals with decision making authority, information and expertise to assist the parties during the settlement process. (
) The FTS AO may ask the taxpayer and the agent to limit the number of pants at the FTS Session to facilitate the process.
Both parties can withdraw at any time during the FTS process. A party wishing to withdraw must provide written notice to the FTS AO and other party.
The FTS Session may also include other individuals with decision making authority, information and expertise to assist the parties during the
Procedures

) IRS employees, the taxpayer, and persons invited to participate by the IRS the taxpayer must not voluntarily disclose information about any tion made during the FTS Session, except as provided by statute. (
) Before the FTS Session, the FTS AO will advise the participants of the dures and establish ground rules. (
) The FTS Session may include joint sessions with all parties, separate meetings, or both as determined appropriate in the FTS AO’s judgment. (
) The FTS AO may modify the rules and procedures during the FTS Session adapt to changes in circumstances. (
) The taxpayer is not required to have a representative to participate in the process, but if they do, this individual must have a valid power of attorney the taxpayer (Form
, Power of Attorney and Declaration of Representa- tive). (

) During the FTS Session, the FTS AO will prepare the FTS Session Agenda and the FTS Session Report and provide both parties with copies. a. The FTS Agenda guides the communication in the FTS Session, sets order of issue discussion, and poses questions to clarify the issues. b. The FTS Report includes a list of all issues approved for the FTS program, a description of the issues, the amounts in dispute, dates, a plan of action for the FTS Session and other information to the process as determined by the parties and the FTS AO. Note: The FTS AO updates the FTS Report after the FTS Session with the developments of the session. (
) Generally, the FTS AO will consider only those issues outlined in the FTS Report, except by mutual agreement of the parties. (

) If the taxpayer presents information during the FTS Session that the had not previously presented during the audit, the FTS AO will adjust the targeted completion date to give the appropriate IRS officials time to the information. (
) During the FTS Session, the FTS AO may propose settlement terms for any all issues, and may consider settlement terms proposed by either party. (

) If the parties resolve any disputed issue at the conclusion of the FTS a. The parties and the FTS AO sign the FTS Report acknowledging tance of the terms of settlement for purposes of preparing b. The case is processed under normal case processing procedures. Note: The signature of the parties on the FTS Report does not constitute a ﬁnal settlement, nor does it waive restrictions on assessment, terminate to extend periods of limitation, start the running of any periods of or constitute agreement to close the case. (

) If the taxpayer accepts the FTS AO’s settlement proposal, but the EP group manager rejects it, the EP Area Manager must review the settlement and either concur in writing with the rejection or accept the settlement on behalf of EP. If the Area Manager: Internal Revenue Manual

During the FTS Session, the FTS AO may propose settlement terms for any or all issues, and may consider settlement terms proposed by either party.
If the parties resolve any disputed issue at the conclusion of the FTS Session:
Employee Plans Examination of Returns

a. Accepts the settlement proposal, the case is processed under estab- lished procedures for an agreed case. b. Concurs with the group manager’s rejection of the settlement proposal, and an acceptable alternative settlement is not reached, the issue is closed out of the FTS program as unagreed. (
) If the parties cannot reach an agreement, process the case under normal “unagreed” procedures. a. See IRM

procedures. b. See IRM

) A resolution reached by the parties through the FTS process will not bind the parties for taxable periods or issues not covered by the FTS agreement, such taxable periods or issues are addressed expressly in a closing reached as part of the FTS process. (
) If applicable, the IRS will report a proposed resolution reached as a result of EP FTS to the Joint Committee on Taxation in accordance with IRC

a. The IRS may reconsider a proposed settlement, as reﬂected in a signed FTS Session Report, upon receipt of comments on the proposed settle- ment from the Joint Committee on Taxation. b. If the taxpayer declines to agree with any changes by the IRS upon re- consideration, EP will close the case unagreed, and the taxpayer will retain all the usual rights to request Appeals consideration of any unagreed issues.
